_prev_prog_3.PHA_OtherTechnique: Seismic hazard identified in Section 7.4(d), was conducted based on the California Accidental Release Prevention Program, 19 California Code of Regulation 2735.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Operator survelliance and truck loader attendance during product transfer operations.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: All compressors, deluge systems and ESD valves.
_prev_prog_3.Description: Storage Tank V-1 containing Natural Gasoline is a 31,690 gallon (water capactiy) pressure vessel designed to ASME Section VIII Pressure Vessel Code.  Installation of this tank and all associated equipment is designed to meet NFPA 58 LPG Standard as well.  The tank has two supply/load lines of which one is a 3" line and the second is a 2" line.  ESDs are in service on both lines at the first flange from the tank.  The tank is protected from overpressure by three parallel PSVs set at 250 psig.  Maximum allowable product level is 85% or 26,937 gallons.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Kern Co. HM & Health Serv. Dept.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
California Accidental Release Prevention Program
Enterprise Products Operating L.P.
Bakersfield Terminal
RMP Executive Summary

The Bakersfield Terminal is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) storage facility.  The process is regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and Cal OSHA Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, Title 8 California Code of Regulations 5189 and 19 California Cod of Regulations 2735 California Accidental Release Prevention Program.  This is a RMP/CalARP Program Level 3 facility.

Enterprise Products Operating L.P. recently acquired the facility from Coast Energy Group and is in the process of implementing the Enterprise Process Safety Management Systems.  The Bakersfield Terminal has a commitment to employee and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases.  However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The prevention program is based on the requirements of 19 California Code of Regulations 2735 California Accidental Release Prevention Program and includes the following:  Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor Evaluation, Contractor and Visitor Orientation, Pre-Job Start-Up Review, Mechanical Integrity, Code of Safe Work Practices (Hot Work Permit, Confined Space Entry, Control of Hazardous Energy), Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, and Compliance Audit.

Training includes employee responsibilities in the process safety management program, National Propane Gas Association - certified employee training program, hot work permit procedure, code of safe work

practices, and operating procedures.  All visitors entering the property must undergo a site safety orientation and check-in prior to each visit.  Planned changes to improve safety have been established based on compliance with the process safety management audits and revalidation of the process hazard analysis.  The last process hazard analysis revalidation was in May of 1999 and is scheduled for revalidation in the spring of 2004.

The Terminal receives, stores and distributes LPG and natural gasoline by rail cars and/or transport trucks.  There are 30 tanks with a capacity of approximately 40,000 gallons each and 5 tanks with a capacity of approximately 32,000 gallons each.  The tanks are administratively controlled to hold LPG or natural gasoline at 85% maximum capacity, which are 34,000 gallons and 27,200 gallons respectively.

Enterprise Products Operating L.P. maintains an emergency response plan in compliance with local emergency response agencies.  The Bakersfield Terminal has recently updated the facility's Hazardous Materials Business Plan and is on file with Kern County Environmental Health Department - Certified Unified Program Agency.  The facility maintains an air permit to operate with the San Joaquin Unified Air Pollution Control District.


In the event of an accidental release, the facility operators are trained to sound the alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate one of the emergency shutdown devices, contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the Bakersfield Police and Fire Departments.

Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10 and 19 CCR 2735.4, this facility has not had an accidental release.  This information was verified by the reviewing of records from the Kern County Environmental Health Department - Certified Unified Program Agency.

The worst-case release scenario simulated a failure of the Storage Tank shell.  The specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting

of the Risk Management Plan.  In addition, although there are numerous controls in place, none were taken into account for mitigating the worst-case scenario.  The alternative release scenario for this process is a hose rupture while pumping natural gasoline.  This scenario assumed the pump continued to operate at a rate of 255 gallons per minutes (gpm) for 10 minutes after the hose ruptured.  The simulation calculated that 13,270 pounds of material were released in the assumed time frame.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  This consisted of reviewing the use of relief valves, check valves, manual shutoff valves, automatic shutoffs, startup and operating procedures, grounding equipment, and excess flow devices.  The facility operator and truck driver are also in attendance during transfer operations.

A preliminary seismic walkthrough was conducted to fulfill the requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program, 19 CCR 2745.7 (q)(2).

The preliminary seismic walkthrough consisted of a visual inspection of the process piping and vessels above grade.  Structural integrity below grade was not inspected.  Walkthrough considerations included the mechanical integrity of pipe, pipe supports, vessels and vessel supports, welds, flanges, valves, pressure safety valves, signs of surface corrosion, pipe stress points, foundations, drainage direction fire control and interaction with other elements.

The reference used for this walkthrough were the following:

API Standard 570 Pressure Vessel Inspection Code:  Maintenance Inspection, Rating, Repair and Alteration.

Process Unlimited International, Inc., Engineered Safety Section, CalARP Seismic Assessment Procedure, April 12, 1999.

Uniform Building Code, 1997 Edition, International Conference of Building Officials.

Based on the document, Maps of Known Active Fault Near-Source Zones in California and Adjacent Portions of Nevada:  Uniform Building C

ode 1997, this facility resides outside the boundaries of the Near-Source Fault Zone.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise Products Operating L.P. is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Note:  In the RMP report, there is indication of "RMP Submittal Warning" in the area of "Date of most recent PSSR", "Date of most recent incident investigation", and "Date of completion of any changes resulting from investigation".  This is due to the fact that there has not been any significant change that resulted or triggered a PSSR, and there has not been any incident that has resulted or triggered an incident investigation.  Therefore those items are left blank and indicate the submittal warnings.
RMP Executive Summary    Page 1 of 3    5/3/2004

Therefore those items are left blank and indicate the submittal warnings.
